p: Nevertheless, 20â€“30% of HIV-1 infected individuals develop, after two or three years of infection, bnAbs able to block infection by diverse viruses from multiple subtypes [ 27, 28, 29]. Generally, this development correlates with high plasma viremia, increased viral diversity, and lower CD4+ T-cell counts [ 30, 31, 32]. The delayed bnAb response could be attributed to a slow antigen-dependent affinity maturation process and seems to result from exposure to an evolving antigen over many years [ 33, 34, 35]. Although bnAb responses fail to control viremia once infection has been established, a vaccine able to generate such responses prior to viral exposure could effectively prevent infection in humans, as the appropriate antibodies would be present before HIV diversification.
